title: Big Data for Social Good
segmentation: I hate needles like it's one of these things that I've had a phobia with for most of my life.
But back in this is like 2000, 2006, 2007.
I was working at a hospital in rural Kenya and was approached by these two nurses and their panicked.
There's been a tattoo accident, a big bus crash and they had run out of blood at the local blood bank and they needed to do a blood transfusion.
And you know, there's really only one thing you do in order to merge and see your in rural Africa.
These nurses asked for your blood.
You suck it up and you close your eyes and you do it and you feel really brave afterwards and you like to show everyone your bruise.
And so that's what happened for me.
And what was striking was about three weeks later I got approached by a different nurse with exactly the same story.
There's been this massive accident we run out of blood at the local blood bank.
We need it.
We need to do it.
Urgency transfusion, we need your blood again now.
By the fourth time this happened I started yet out of my own kind of personal interest trying to understand what the deal was with blood supplies and rural Kenya like.
Why did these blood banks keep running out of blood?
An you know we built at this point in time I was I was I was doing some work with the University of Nairobi as well and we together some students but a little SMS blood bank system.
A system that let us allow these.
Actually these nurses to text in what the current blood supply levels were.

And there are hospitals and we built this beautiful visualization to allow the guys at the centralized blood banks in Mombasa and elsewhere across the country to see in real time what the blood levels were.
Even more importantly, where the blood was needed.
And previously, what they've literally been doing.
This is a guy in a pickup truck and he would be going from hospital hospital and looking at the blood supply levels.
And then it goes below certain threshold.
You know, the next two week trip you'd come by and refill them so you had a latency in the current system with almost almost a month.
So we thought this was a pretty clever solution.
Enabled the nurses, they all had cell phones to be able to start providing real time data.
And the first week was a big success and we had we were on we in the newspaper were shaking the Ministry of Health hand and the nurses were texting in the data that guys were always logging in.
I I felt like this is pretty clever and the second week we had the system live about half the nurses stop texting in the data.
An by the end of the first month, virtually no one was using our system anymore and ultimately was deemed a failure, and that system failed not because of any technical shortcoming.
Technically this thing was rock solid.
It failed because of a fundamental lack of insight on my part about the price of a text message.
The price that people incur when trying to consume or or send data.
It turns out that the price of a text message represents a fairly substantial fraction of a rural nurses days wage.
So to you know, by asking these nurses to everyday tell us what, how much blood they had in their local blood bank.
We were essentially asking them to take a pay cut.
You know something that was inherently unfair.
You know, I was at this point in time.
Kind of really in a very lucky situation.
My background is large scale data analytics, specifically with mobile operators.
At this point in time I had read write access to the back end billing systems of virtually every mobile operator in East Africa.

So it's really kind of in this unique position where actually I mean, I wrote basically a 20 line Python script script that for the proper, every properly formatted text message with these was apply levels.
We would credit that rural nurse like it was ten Kenyan shillings, enough to cover the cost of the SMS and like a penny to say thank you.
And for the opportunity to literally earn like 1 cent worth of airtime, virtually every rural nursery engaged in the platform an it started.
It's now something that's being deployed across East Africa.
But more importantly, it kind of triggered flips.
Basically, a switch flipped with these operators that have been working with helping them understand Cdr Analytics that suddenly they were starting to take money not out of that rule.
Nurses pocket, but they're starting to take money out of the Kenyan Ministry of Health Pocket.
And they're desperate for alternative revenue sources.
And so they wanted to see how this thing could scale.
So you know they incentivized me to to leave my academic academic job at MIT and basically go out an try to build this business.
This business of essentially paying mobile phone subscribers and emerging markets to get data from them and.
We had.
We've scaled basically the first couple of years we onboarded maybe dozens of mobile operators.
If you Fast forward today.
We've integrated with 237 mobile operators.
We're live now in 100 and two countries and we can do something that I think is quite profound.
We can literally put money into the pockets of 3.48 billion people.
Yeah, across 1 two countries and something like 76 currencies, no friction free and in denominations as low as $0.10.
No other company has anything close to that kind of capability.
An the open question is like so alright so we have the ability now to put money into the pockets of virtually half of our species.
Where is that money going to come from and what kind of data will be required to for people to provide to make this happen?

You know we've used this platform for clients ranging from the World Bank or calculating purchasing power Parity Aljazeera, where we're getting sentiments you know people's opinions of the Pakistani election and it's neat.

I mean it's cool to be able to start seeing how this sort of thing is transforming individuals who heretofore have been kind of invisible to the Aljazeera global audience and turning their data into news and enabling their voices to be heard.

Now we're pushing at the moment about $10,000 a day into people's pockets, and I think it's you know we're on track to be at $100,000 a day by this time next year, and it's pretty interesting to be able to start seeing how this sort of business.
Has growing as large organizations are becoming cognizant of the value of data in these emerging markets.

So what I'm going to be talking about for the rest of this talk is is kind of the top down big data data coming from organizations like mobile operators as well as increasingly organizations like Facebook.

This slide gets better and better.

As well as a unique identifier for the caller and the recipient, and what you can do then is start building out all sorts of interesting inference about the dynamics of the population and.

One of the things that we've been also kind of looking at is beyond just thinking about parameterizing movement.
Can we start inferring underlying outcomes of interest based on this type of data?
So looking at figuring out, can you infer gender confer economic prosperity?
One of the the papers that we originally did to identify this was actually in the UK.

We're looking at virtually every phone call made in the UK at during a particular month and what was striking is that we're coupling this with average income access to healthcare education levels and the surprising thing, at least from my perspective, was it wasn't.
You know, these outcomes of interest weren't correlated with how much you use your phone.
Well, they weren't correlated.
Even with like you know how many friends you had in your network, so your degree, but rather the thing that was really striking.
Was these outcomes of interest were highly correlated with diversity?
Like so we took, we created a metric of, you know, that's a variance of Shannon entropy.
Looking at the diversity of individual networks, we were able to see that there's a striking relationship between how diverse your network is, where your diversity is like looking at.
Are your friends from similar regions?
Are your friends have similar metrics to you if you are?

In a homogeneous network you are much less likely to have good access to healthcare and higher education outcomes then the individuals that had high diversity, which then leads to this question of causality, right an it's still one that I think has been a difficult thing to solve, especially when you're approaching a lot of these problems from that top down mentality of just taking a lot of aggregate data without actually querying and individuals.
Because perhaps these prosperous people are have more access to opportunities and that diversity is simply a byproduct of being prosperous.
Or, you know, the diversity is causing the prosperity and it's.
It's still a work in progress.
As as we started better quantifying how to at least these salient metrics associated with positive economic outcomes, we could start applying that to emerging markets.

An what was interesting was that we could start identifying particular regions where when people move to that region, suddenly these these factors that are correlated with economic economic prosperity start increasing an in many instances.

A lot of these regions are where the big slums are, so this is where we did a particular study in this case was in Kenya, Kibera, one of the largest slums in the world, and we're actually starting to be able to see how as people are moving, moving to these regions.
Suddenly these you start seeing them start paying more for their mobile phones, start being able to increase the diversity of their networks, and then ultimately springboarding to another place.

It was relatively easy to be able to show that you simply can't eradicate malaria in that one part of Kenya.

And you know, there's really only one thing you do in order to merge and see your in rural Africa.
These nurses asked for your blood.
You suck it up and you close your eyes and you do it and you feel really brave afterwards and you like to show everyone your bruise.
And so that's what happened for me.
And what was striking was about three weeks later I got approached by a different nurse with exactly the same story.
There's been this massive accident we run out of blood at the local blood bank.
We need it.
We need to do it.
Urgency transfusion, we need your blood again now.
By the fourth time this happened I started yet out of my own kind of personal interest trying to understand what the deal was with blood supplies and rural Kenya like.
Why did these blood banks keep running out of blood?
An you know we built at this point in time I was I was I was doing some work with the University of Nairobi as well and we together some students but a little SMS blood bank system.
A system that let us allow these.
Actually these nurses to text in what the current blood supply levels were.

And there are hospitals and we built this beautiful visualization to allow the guys at the centralized blood banks in Mombasa and elsewhere across the country to see in real time what the blood levels were.
Even more importantly, where the blood was needed.
And previously, what they've literally been doing.
This is a guy in a pickup truck and he would be going from hospital hospital and looking at the blood supply levels.
And then it goes below certain threshold.
You know, the next two week trip you'd come by and refill them so you had a latency in the current system with almost almost a month.
So we thought this was a pretty clever solution.
Enabled the nurses, they all had cell phones to be able to start providing real time data.
And the first week was a big success and we had we were on we in the newspaper were shaking the Ministry of Health hand and the nurses were texting in the data that guys were always logging in.
I I felt like this is pretty clever and the second week we had the system live about half the nurses stop texting in the data.

Technically this thing was rock solid.
It failed because of a fundamental lack of insight on my part about the price of a text message.
The price that people incur when trying to consume or or send data.
It turns out that the price of a text message represents a fairly substantial fraction of a rural nurses days wage.
So to you know, by asking these nurses to everyday tell us what, how much blood they had in their local blood bank.
We were essentially asking them to take a pay cut.
You know something that was inherently unfair.
